content:
# The furnace is currently working and has successfully smelted 1 iron plate, with 8 iron ores remaining. 
# My inventory has updated accordingly, showing that I now have 1 stone furnace, 5 coal, and 10 stones left.

# To maximize production, I should consider placing the second stone furnace as well, allowing for simultaneous smelting of iron ore.
# I will place the second furnace next to the first one to create an efficient smelting setup.

# First, I will determine the position to place the second furnace next to the first one.
# Using the drop position of the first furnace as a reference, I will place the second furnace.
second_furnace_position = Position(x=furnace.position.x + 2, y=furnace.position.y)  # Adjust position for spacing
second_furnace = place_entity(Prototype.StoneFurnace, position=second_furnace_position)  # Place the second furnace
assert second_furnace, "Failed to place the second stone furnace."  # Check if the second furnace was placed successfully

# Now, I need to insert coal into the second furnace for it to function.
insert_item(Prototype.Coal, second_furnace, quantity=5)  # Insert coal into the second furnace

# Next, I will also insert some iron ore into the second furnace for smelting.
insert_item(Prototype.IronOre, second_furnace, quantity=10)  # Insert iron ore into the second furnace

# I will now check the inventories of both furnaces to ensure they are set up correctly and functioning.
first_furnace_inventory = inspect_inventory(furnace)  # Check the first furnace's inventory
second_furnace_inventory = inspect_inventory(second_furnace)  # Check the second furnace's inventory

print(f"First furnace inventory: {first_furnace_inventory}")  # Output first furnace inventory
print(f"Second furnace inventory: {second_furnace_inventory}")  # Output second furnace inventory
print(f"Inventory after setup: {inspect_inventory()}")  # Check overall inventory after setup
print(f"Entities on the map: {get_entities()}")  # Check entities on the map again
